paragraphs: March 2012As a child I read a book of stories about a famous judge in eighteenth century Japan called Ooka Tadasuke. One of the cases he decided was brought by the owner of a food shop. A poor student who could afford only rice was eating his rice while enjoying the delicious cooking smells coming from the food shop.

The owner wanted the student to pay for the smells he was enjoying.The student was stealing his smells!This story often comes to mind when I hear the RIAA and MPAA accusing people of stealing music and movies.It sounds ridiculous to us to treat smells as property.

But I can imagine scenarios in which one could charge for smells. Imagine we were living on a moon base where we had to buy air by the liter. I could imagine air suppliers adding scents at an extra charge.The reason it seems ridiculous to us to treat smells as property is that it wouldn't work to.

It would work on a moon base, though.What counts as property depends on what works to treat as property. And that not only can change, but has changed. Humans may always (for some definition of human and always) have treated small items carried on one's person as property.

But hunter gatherers didn't treat land, for example, as property in the way we do. [1]The reason so many people think of property as having a single unchanging definition is that its definition changes very slowly.

[2] But we are in the midst of such a change now. The record labels and movie studios used to distribute what they made like air shipped through tubes on a moon base. But with the arrival of networks, it's as if we've moved to a planet with a breathable atmosphere.

Data moves like smells now. And through a combination of wishful thinking and short-term greed, the labels and studios have put themselves in the position of the food shop owner, accusing us all of stealing their smells.(The reason I say short-term greed is that the underlying problem with the labels and studios is that the people who run them are driven by bonuses rather than equity.

If they were driven by equity they'd be looking for ways to take advantage of technological change instead of fighting it. But building new things takes too long. Their bonuses depend on this year's revenues, and the best way to increase those is to extract more money from stuff they do already.)So what does this mean?

Should people not be able to charge for content? There's not a single yes or no answer to that question. People should be able to charge for content when it works to charge for content.But by "works" I mean something more subtle than "when they can get away with it." I mean when people can charge for content without warping society in order to do it.

After all, the companies selling smells on the moon base could continue to sell them on the Earth, if they lobbied successfully for laws requiring us all to continue to breathe through tubes down here too, even though we no longer needed to.The crazy legal measures that the labels and studios have been taking have a lot of that flavor.
Newspapers and magazines are just as screwed, but they are at least declining gracefully. The RIAA and MPAA would make us breathe through tubes if they could.Ultimately it comes down to common sense.

When you're abusing the legal system by trying to use mass lawsuits against randomly chosen people as a form of exemplary punishment, or lobbying for laws that would break the Internet if they passed, that's ipso facto evidence you're using a definition of property that doesn't work.This is where it's helpful to have working democracies and multiple sovereign countries.

If the world had a single, autocratic government, the labels and studios could buy laws making the definition of property be whatever they wanted. But fortunately there are still some countries that are not copyright colonies of the US, and even in the US, politicians still seem to be afraid of actual voters, in sufficient numbers.

[3]The people running the US may not like it when voters or other countries refuse to bend to their will, but ultimately it's in all our interest that there's not a single point of attack for people trying to warp the law to serve their own purposes.

Private property is an extremely useful idea — arguably one of our greatest inventions. So far, each new definition of it has brought us increasing material wealth. [4] It seems reasonable to suppose the newest one will too.

It would be a disaster if we all had to keep running an obsolete version just because a few powerful people were too lazy to upgrade.Notes[1] If you want to learn more about hunter gatherers I strongly recommend Elizabeth Marshall Thomas's The Harmless People and The Old Way.[2] Change in the definition of property is driven mostly by technological progress, however, and since technological progress is accelerating, so presumably will the rate of change in the definition of property.

Which means it's all the more important for societies to be able to respond gracefully to such changes, because they will come at an ever increasing rate.[3] As far as I know, the term "copyright colony" was first used by Myles Peterson.[4] The state of technology isn't simply a function of the definition of property.

They each constrain the other. But that being so, you can't mess with the definition of property without affecting (and probably harming) the state of technology. The history of the USSR offers a vivid illustration of that.Thanks to Sam Altman and Geoff Ralston for reading drafts of this.Japanese Translation

One of the cases he decided was brought by the owner of a food shop. A poor student who could afford only rice was eating his rice while enjoying the delicious cooking smells coming from the food shop.
paragraphs.translated: 2012年3月当我还是个孩子的时候，我读过一本关于18世纪日本著名法官大冈裁助的故事书。其中一个案件是由一家食品店的老板提起的。一个贫穷的学生只能买得起米饭，他一边吃着米饭，一边享受着从食品店里飘出的美味饭菜的香气。

paragraphs.original: The owner wanted the student to pay for the smells he was enjoying.The student was stealing his smells!This story often comes to mind when I hear the RIAA and MPAA accusing people of stealing music and movies.It sounds ridiculous to us to treat smells as property.
paragraphs.translated: 主人希望学生为他所享受的气味付费。学生是在窃取他的气味！每当我听到美国唱片业协会（RIAA）和美国电影协会（MPAA）指责人们窃取音乐和电影时，总会想到这个故事。把气味当作财产来对待，在我们看来是荒谬的。

paragraphs.translated: 但我可以想象这样的场景：可以对气味收费。设想我们生活在一个月球基地上，不得不按升购买空气。我可以想象空气供应商会额外收费添加香氛。我们觉得把气味当作财产处理是荒谬的原因是，这样做根本行不通。

paragraphs.original: It would work on a moon base, though.What counts as property depends on what works to treat as property. And that not only can change, but has changed. Humans may always (for some definition of human and always) have treated small items carried on one's person as property.
paragraphs.translated: 它可以在月球基地上运作。什么算作财产取决于什么可以被当作财产来处理。这不仅可能会改变，而且确实已经改变了。人类可能一直（对于某种定义的人类和一直）将随身携带的小物品视为财产。

paragraphs.original: But hunter gatherers didn't treat land, for example, as property in the way we do. [1]The reason so many people think of property as having a single unchanging definition is that its definition changes very slowly.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，狩猎采集者并不会像我们今天这样将土地视为财产。[1]许多人认为财产有一个固定不变的定义，其原因是财产的定义变化非常缓慢。

paragraphs.original: [2] But we are in the midst of such a change now. The record labels and movie studios used to distribute what they made like air shipped through tubes on a moon base. But with the arrival of networks, it's as if we've moved to a planet with a breathable atmosphere.
paragraphs.translated: [2] 但我们正处于这样的变革之中。唱片公司和电影制片厂过去分发他们制作的内容，就像在月球基地通过管道输送空气一样。但随着网络的出现，这就好像我们搬到了一个有可呼吸大气层的星球。

paragraphs.translated: 数据如今像气味一样传播。由于一厢情愿和短期贪婪的结合，唱片公司和电影制片厂将自己置于食品店老板的位置，指责我们所有人盗取了他们的气味。（我说短期贪婪的原因是，唱片公司和电影制片厂的根本问题是，经营这些公司的人受到奖金而非股权的驱动。

Their bonuses depend on this year's revenues, and the best way to increase those is to extract more money from stuff they do already.)So what does this mean?
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们受股权驱动，他们会寻找利用技术变革的方法，而不是与之抗争。但建立新事物需要太长时间。他们的奖金取决于今年的收入，而增加收入的最好方法是从他们已经在做的事情中提取更多的钱。那么这意味着什么呢？

paragraphs.original: Should people not be able to charge for content? There's not a single yes or no answer to that question. paragraphs.translated: 人们不应该对内容收费吗？这个问题没有简单的答案。当收费模式可行时，人们应该能够对内容收费。但我说的“可行”不仅仅是指“他们能够做到这一点”。我的意思是，在不扭曲社会的前提下，人们能够对内容收费。

paragraphs.original: After all, the companies selling smells on the moon base could continue to sell them on the Earth, if they lobbied successfully for laws requiring us all to continue to breathe through tubes down here too, even though we no longer needed to.The crazy legal measures that the labels and studios have been taking have a lot of that flavor.
paragraphs.translated: 毕竟，如果那些在月球基地卖气味的公司成功游说通过法律，要求我们即使不再需要也必须继续通过管子呼吸，那么他们仍然可以在地球上继续销售这些气味。唱片公司和电影制片厂采取的那些疯狂的法律措施，就有这种味道。

paragraphs.original: Newspapers and magazines are just as screwed, but they are at least declining gracefully. The RIAA and MPAA would make us breathe through tubes if they could.Ultimately it comes down to common sense.
paragraphs.translated: 报纸和杂志也一样糟糕，但至少它们是在体面地衰退。RIAA和MPAA如果可以的话，会让我们通过管子呼吸。归根结底，这还是一个常识问题。

paragraphs.original: When you're abusing the legal system by trying to use mass lawsuits against randomly chosen people as a form of exemplary punishment, or lobbying for laws that would break the Internet if they passed, that's ipso facto evidence you're using a definition of property that doesn't work.This is where it's helpful to have working democracies and multiple sovereign countries.
paragraphs.translated: 当你滥用了法律系统，试图通过针对随机选择的人提起大规模诉讼作为示范惩罚，或者游说通过那些一旦实施将破坏互联网的法律时，这本身就是证据，表明你使用的财产定义是行不通的。在这种情况下，拥有运作良好的民主制度和多个主权国家是有帮助的。

paragraphs.original: If the world had a single, autocratic government, the labels and studios could buy laws making the definition of property be whatever they wanted. But fortunately there are still some countries that are not copyright colonies of the US, and even in the US, politicians still seem to be afraid of actual voters, in sufficient numbers.
paragraphs.translated: 如果世界上有一个独裁的政府，唱片公司和电影制片厂就可以购买法律，使财产的定义成为他们所希望的任何内容。但幸运的是，仍然有一些国家不是美国的版权殖民地，甚至在美国，政客们似乎仍然害怕数量足够的实际选民。

paragraphs.original: [3]The people running the US may not like it when voters or other countries refuse to bend to their will, but ultimately it's in all our interest that there's not a single point of attack for people trying to warp the law to serve their own purposes.
paragraphs.translated: [3]美国的执政者可能不喜欢选民或其他国家不屈从于他们的意志，但最终，确保没有人能通过一个单一的攻击点来扭曲法律以服务于自己的目的，这符合所有人的利益。

paragraphs.original: Private property is an extremely useful idea — arguably one of our greatest inventions. So far, each new definition of it has brought us increasing material wealth. [4] It seems reasonable to suppose the newest one will too.
paragraphs.translated: 私有财产是一个极其有用的观念——可以说是我们的最伟大发明之一。到目前为止，每一次对其定义的更新都为我们带来了越来越多的物质财富。[4] 有理由相信，最新的定义也将如此。

paragraphs.original: It would be a disaster if we all had to keep running an obsolete version just because a few powerful people were too lazy to upgrade.Notes[1] If you want to learn more about hunter gatherers I strongly recommend Elizabeth Marshall Thomas's The Harmless People and The Old Way.[2] Change in the definition of property is driven mostly by technological progress, however, and since technological progress is accelerating, so presumably will the rate of change in the definition of property.
paragraphs.translated: 如果我们所有人都因为少数有权力的人懒得升级而不得不继续使用过时的版本，那将是一场灾难。注释[1] 如果你想要了解更多关于狩猎采集者的信息，我强烈推荐伊丽莎白·马歇尔·托马斯的《无害的人》和《古老的方式》。[2] 财产权定义的变化主要由技术进步推动，而由于技术进步正在加速，因此财产权定义变化的速率也可能会加速。

paragraphs.original: Which means it's all the more important for societies to be able to respond gracefully to such changes, because they will come at an ever increasing rate.[3] As far as I know, the term "copyright colony" was first used by Myles Peterson.[4] The state of technology isn't simply a function of the definition of property.
paragraphs.translated: 这意味着社会能够优雅地应对这些变化变得尤为重要，因为这些变化将以越来越快的速度到来。据我所知，“版权殖民地”这一术语最早由迈尔斯·彼得森使用。技术状态不仅仅是财产定义的函数。
